clinical_study.brief_title: The Perioperative Anesthetic Management and the Prognosis of Patients Undergoing Brain Malignant Glioma Resection
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Anesthetic Management on the Outcome of Patients With Brain Tumors.

brief_summary.textblock: Although bench data and retrospective studies have provided a promising picture of the possible influence of anesthetic technique on the risk of tumor progression, current evidence from RCTs is inadequate to show whether the type of anesthetics might influence tumor progression.There are many thousands of patients with a cancer diagnosis undergoing surgery every year, and in the context of biological plausibility, it should lead to the urgent undertaking of RCTs to further evaluate the association between the anesthetic management and postoperative malignant glioma progression.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: This is a single centre, randomized, parallel group controlled clinical trial in patients with primary HGG. All eligible patients will be 1:1 randomized to the TIVA or INHA group. The object of the trail is to evaluate the effect of propofol or sevoflurane on the prognosis of HGG patients after craniotomy.
study_design_info.masking_description: The anesthesiologist know the grouping .The subjects and the outcome assesor trained for telephone visit were blinded to the grouping

primary_outcome.description: progression free survival rate at postoperative 6 months

arm_group.description: Patients will receive total intravenous anesthesia undergoing brain tumor resection.
Patients will receive volatile inhalational anesthesia undergoing brain tumor resection.

intervention.description: The patients will receive intravenous anesthesia
The patients will receive inhalation anesthesia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Malignant glioma is defined as high-grade glioma according to the fourth edition of the World Health Organization (WHO) classification of tumors of the central nervous system.
The patient included is older than 18 years.
Exclusion Criteria:
- The patients with recurrent glioma or low-grade glioma (WHO I-II) will be excluded from the study.
Recurred brain tumor
